content: Added "write answer" to stub generator so that the initial default code shows the syntax for debugging and outputting the answer.

You could upper the limit a bit, as prime factorization is O(sqrt(n)) - or even faster with a good algo. I just solved it with an O(n) solution to see if it passes.

In any case give an upper bound for n in the constraints, then I'll approve.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

I upvoted this because it is stimulating some math considerations, that I love when happens in programming.
The answer "longest suite" can be obtained without brute force, so it is challenging.
I want just to verify it is possible also to answer to the "number of valid solutions" without brute force combinations checking.... in that case it will be perfect.

Hi, doing a bit of math, it comes out that the problem is about:
given N, find two integers K (odd) and L such as:
N=L(L+K-1)  ⇒ K=N/L-L+1
and such as:
N>=L^2

So basically finding the longest suite is about to find L as the biggest factor of N less than his square, then the sequence starts from K=N/L-L+1 and is long L.

Example: 1001=7×11×13 , so the biggest factor less than 31.6 is L=13, so the sequence starts from K=1001/13-13+1=65

Example: 8167415=5×23×29×31×79 , so the biggest factor less than 2857.9 is L=2449, so the sequence starts from K=8167415/2449-2449+1=887

So the problem is to inspect all combinations of the prime factors of N to find this max factor L.
I cannot solve this (well just the first cases where a brute force does the trick).  I also don't understand your solution.
It is true that we can think like 15=15, then test 1's output will be 2/3 7
Test 3 is out of output specs.

More braindead:

15 = 15

Maybe it's because I'm tired, but I don't get it:
testcase 1: the sequence consists of all odd numbers from 3 to 5 (so only 3 and 5). The sum of them is 8, not 15.
in testcase 2 you suddenly have even numbers.

I see that the product of both always returns the input value, but I don't see the relation to the statement.

oups ... you're right , i made a mistake when publishing the puzzle

i have fixed it with good solution and good tests

humm , you are right ... 

i have not thought about this possibility

i'll specify that the numbers must be positive
(for those wondering, "at least two" was not in the problem statement at time of writing)

SUM : result of adding two or more numbers

15 is not a sum

OK, I finally managed to get all solutions right, but I needed to use the old thing I learned 20 years ago (I think it was called "mathematics") and I still need -O2. Some comments to your solutions would be interesting.
Yes, just complete with a constraint, and I will approve it too.

added constraint for n

added tests for high values of n

I edited your code generator to read a long instead of int.
A bit mean to cause an integer overflow (for singed 32bit) only on submit.
thanks

Sorry to bother you again, but I miss a test with a big prime number (e.g. 4294967291)
Your code times out on this.
I had to refine a bit the factorization function for such size of numbers. Nice suggestion to let people dig a bit on factorization theory.

To be honest, the case in which the input is a prime number is the non-interesting one.
The more stressing input is the max number < 2^32 that is product of two primes, possibly both near his radix, i.e. something like 4292870399(=65521x65519),
but for factorizating such number is enough the simplest algoritm.

i was sure that some big primes tests will timeout ... that's php ... ;)

now , i'll have to spend times to optimize my solution or change language
(may cheat with bash ... but less fun :D )

I think for not timeout on 4292870399(=65521x65519),
you just need to skip the tests on even numbers (i+=2 vs i++)  ;)  (this will about half your calc time)

Your code is like: for (int i = 2; i <= n; i++) // not exactly, but same idea
You could do it with i*i <= n

The solution should not be O(N^2), but something about O(N/log(N)) , since it is only about to work with the combinations of the prime factors of N.
That sweet old math ;)
Ah, now i understanded.
That doesn't appear to still be an issue in the current statement wording, but FTR common algebra accepts 1- and 0-terms sums just fine.

Still... no.

Not sure this is the correct parse, but this is what my brain currently reads: "In this puzzle you'll have to find out whether it's possible to [blah blah blah] and the longest solution"

Nope, I'm not there yet.

Let's dig in the blah.
"[possible to] get the number proposed by a sum of consecutive odd numbers"

Really not there yet.

May I suggest specifying in more/actual detail:
* "get" = ? compute? deduce? guess?
* "proposed" probably not the right word for the context, but I can't tell for sure yet
* "consecutive odd" err that's not really how naturals work

I know it's late and I'm tired. But still?
